title: Psychogenic Non-Epileptic Spells (PNES)
icd10: ** F44.5 (Conversion disorder with seizures or convulsions)
scope: ** Diagnosis, acute management, and long-term treatment of psychogenic non-epileptic spells (PNES). Covers the diagnostic workup including video-EEG confirmation, semiology features distinguishing PNES from epileptic seizures, diagnosis delivery as a therapeutic intervention, psychotherapy (CBT as evidence-based treatment), management of psychiatric comorbidities (PTSD, depression, anxiety), and anti-seizure medication taper. Addresses the ~10% of PNES patients with comorbid epilepsy. Settings: ED (acute event management), HOSP (video-EEG monitoring and diagnosis), OPD (long-term therapy and follow-up). ICU is generally NOT applicable for PNES. For epileptic seizures, see "New Onset Seizure" and "Status Epilepticus" templates. For the broader category of functional neurological disorder, see "FND" template.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Baseline; rule out infection or anemia as contributor to altered consciousness
Metabolic encephalopathy screen; electrolyte abnormalities can provoke both epileptic and non-epileptic events
Hypoglycemia as event mimic; altered consciousness differential
Thyroid dysfunction contributing to anxiety, mood disturbance, or tremor
UTI as contributor to altered mental status; drug screen
Elevated >2x baseline supports epileptic seizure; NORMAL post-event supports PNES diagnosis; must be drawn within 10-20 min of event onset
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal in PNES (elevated >2x baseline suggests epileptic seizure)

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Substance intoxication/withdrawal as event precipitant; establish baseline for psychiatric treatment
Inflammatory screen if autoimmune etiology suspected
Inflammatory screen if autoimmune or infectious etiology suspected
B12 deficiency contributing to neuropsychiatric symptoms
Diabetic neuropathy or metabolic contributor; baseline for psychiatric medication management
If patient on ASMs, verify compliance and levels before diagnosing "breakthrough seizures" as PNES

Rare/Specialized.rationale: If acute onset with psychiatric features, movement disorder, or cognitive decline suggestive of anti-NMDAR encephalitis
If atypical features or suspicion for paraneoplastic neurological syndrome
Adrenal insufficiency presenting as recurrent syncope-like episodes

Essential/First-line.target: Normal; rules out hemorrhage, mass, or acute structural lesion

Acute/Emergent (Event Management in ED).indication: Active PNES event; first-line acute management

doseOptions.orderSentence: Verbal reassurance and grounding techniques (first-line) N/A -

dosing.instructions: Use calm, reassuring voice; say "You are safe, I am here to help you"; guide grounding (name 5 things you see, 4 you hear, 3 you touch); do NOT restrain, force oral airway, or attempt IV access during event
dosing.orderSentence: Verbal reassurance and grounding techniques (first-line) N/A -

Acute/Emergent (Event Management in ED).monitoring: Event duration; response to verbal cues; vital signs; document semiology features

Acute/Emergent (Event Management in ED).indication: Do NOT administer benzodiazepines for confirmed or suspected PNES; benzodiazepines cause respiratory depression without benefit; leading cause of iatrogenic intubation in PNES

dosing.instructions: Withhold lorazepam, midazolam, diazepam; if epileptic seizure cannot be excluded, treat per status epilepticus protocol while awaiting clarification

Acute/Emergent (Event Management in ED).contraindications: If epileptic seizure cannot be excluded, treat as epileptic until proven otherwise
Acute/Emergent (Event Management in ED).monitoring: Respiratory status; level of consciousness; document clinical features to aid differentiation

Acute/Emergent (Event Management in ED).indication: Do NOT load IV phenytoin, levetiracetam, or valproate for confirmed or suspected PNES; ineffective and delays correct diagnosis

dosing.instructions: Withhold IV ASM loading; if comorbid epilepsy is established and epileptic seizure possible, continue home ASMs

Acute/Emergent (Event Management in ED).contraindications: Comorbid epilepsy with possible epileptic breakthrough
Acute/Emergent (Event Management in ED).monitoring: Document event semiology; EEG if available

Acute/Emergent (Event Management in ED).indication: Functional unresponsiveness; aids differentiation from epileptic postictal state

doseOptions.orderSentence: Nasal ammonia capsule (smelling salts) 1 capsule INH

dosing.instructions: Break capsule 6 inches from nose; grimace or withdrawal response confirms awareness and supports functional diagnosis
dosing.orderSentence: Nasal ammonia capsule (smelling salts) 1 capsule INH

Acute/Emergent (Event Management in ED).indication: Injury prevention during active PNES event

dosing.instructions: Place patient in safe position; pad side rails if in bed; remove nearby sharp objects; do NOT insert bite block or tongue blade; position on side if secretions present

Diagnosis Delivery (\"The Name\").indication: All PNES patients after diagnostic confirmation; the single most important therapeutic intervention

dosing.instructions: Explain: "You have a condition called functional seizures (or non-epileptic events). These are REAL events, not fabricated. Your brain is sending the wrong signals, like a software glitch rather than hardware damage. The good news is this is treatable." Show the patient their vEEG results (normal EEG during event). Use the term "functional seizures" rather than "psychogenic" if patient prefers. Validate the reality of symptoms. Express diagnostic confidence. Emphasize treatability. Provide neurosymptoms.org

Diagnosis Delivery (\"The Name\").monitoring: Patient understanding and acceptance; emotional response; therapeutic alliance; repeat key messages across multiple encounters if needed

Psychotherapy (Primary Treatment).indication: All PNES patients; strongest evidence base (CODES trial); addresses illness beliefs, avoidance, seizure-related cognitions, and perpetuating factors

dosing.instructions: Weekly 50-60 min sessions; PNES-specific CBT model per Goldstein et al. (CODES trial); includes psychoeducation, seizure control techniques, cognitive restructuring of illness beliefs, graded behavioral activation, addressing avoidance, trauma processing if indicated; booster sessions at 3 and 6 months

Psychotherapy (Primary Treatment).contraindications: Active psychosis; severe intellectual disability preventing engagement; active substance dependence (treat first)
Psychotherapy (Primary Treatment).monitoring: Seizure/event frequency diary; PHQ-9; GAD-7; functional measures; treatment engagement

Psychotherapy (Primary Treatment).indication: PNES with PTSD or significant trauma history (present in ~30-50% of patients)

doseOptions.orderSentence: EMDR (Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing) 8-12 sessions -

dosing.instructions: Standard EMDR protocol; 60-90 min sessions; process traumatic memories identified as precipitating or perpetuating PNES; may be combined with CBT
dosing.orderSentence: EMDR (Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing) 8-12 sessions -

Psychotherapy (Primary Treatment).contraindications: Active psychosis; severe dissociative disorder (requires specialist modification); acute suicidality
Psychotherapy (Primary Treatment).monitoring: PCL-5 (PTSD scale); event frequency; dissociation measures (DES); treatment engagement

Psychotherapy (Primary Treatment).indication: PNES with prominent interpersonal difficulties, attachment disturbance, or alexithymia (difficulty identifying emotions)

dosing.instructions: Explore unconscious conflicts, emotional processing difficulties, and relational patterns contributing to PNES; helps patients connect emotional states to physical symptoms

Psychotherapy (Primary Treatment).contraindications: Active psychosis; severe personality disorder (relative contraindication)
Psychotherapy (Primary Treatment).monitoring: Event frequency; functional measures; therapeutic alliance assessment; emotional awareness

Psychotherapy (Primary Treatment).indication: PNES with high anxiety, somatic hypervigilance, or as adjunct to CBT

dosing.instructions: Standard 8-week MBSR program; weekly 2.5-hour sessions plus home practice; body scan modified to reduce somatic hypervigilance; focus on non-reactive awareness of body sensations

Psychotherapy (Primary Treatment).monitoring: GAD-7; mindfulness measures (FFMQ); event frequency; patient-reported stress

Psychotherapy (Primary Treatment).indication: All PNES patients; normalizes experience, reduces isolation, provides peer support

dosing.instructions: Structured group program (6-10 participants); covers PNES education, coping strategies, trigger identification, self-management skills, grounding techniques, relapse prevention

Psychotherapy (Primary Treatment).monitoring: Attendance; knowledge assessment; patient satisfaction; event frequency

Pharmacologic Management of Psychiatric.indication: Comorbid major depression (present in ~50-85% of PNES patients); comorbid anxiety; PTSD (first-line for all three)

dosing.instructions: Start 50 mg daily; titrate by 50 mg q2-4wk; max 200 mg/day; takes 4-6 weeks for full effect

Pharmacologic Management of Psychiatric.contraindications: Concurrent MAOIs (14-day washout); QTc prolongation at high doses
Pharmacologic Management of Psychiatric.monitoring: Suicidality monitoring (first 8 weeks); serotonin syndrome symptoms; QTc if risk factors; sexual side effects

Pharmacologic Management of Psychiatric.indication: Comorbid generalized anxiety disorder; depression; alternative to sertraline

dosing.instructions: Start 10 mg daily; may increase to 20 mg after 4 weeks; max 20 mg/day

Pharmacologic Management of Psychiatric.contraindications: Concurrent MAOIs; QTc prolongation; congenital long QT syndrome
Pharmacologic Management of Psychiatric.monitoring: QTc monitoring if risk factors; serotonin syndrome; hyponatremia in elderly

Pharmacologic Management of Psychiatric.indication: Comorbid depression with prominent anxiety; chronic pain comorbidity (dual SNRI benefit); alternative when SSRIs ineffective

dosing.instructions: Start 37.5 mg daily x 1 week; titrate by 37.5-75 mg q1wk; max 225 mg/day; MUST taper to discontinue (severe discontinuation syndrome)

Pharmacologic Management of Psychiatric.contraindications: Uncontrolled hypertension; concurrent MAOIs; narrow-angle glaucoma
Pharmacologic Management of Psychiatric.monitoring: BP (dose-dependent hypertension); HR; serotonin syndrome; discontinuation syndrome risk (taper over 2-4 weeks)

Pharmacologic Management of Psychiatric.indication: Comorbid depression with chronic pain (common in PNES); fibromyalgia comorbidity

dosing.instructions: Start 30 mg daily x 1 week; increase to 60 mg daily; max 120 mg/day

Pharmacologic Management of Psychiatric.contraindications: Hepatic impairment (CrCl <30); concurrent MAOIs; uncontrolled narrow-angle glaucoma
Pharmacologic Management of Psychiatric.monitoring: LFTs; BP; serotonin syndrome; discontinuation syndrome (taper slowly)

Pharmacologic Management of Psychiatric.indication: PTSD-related nightmares and sleep disruption (common in PNES patients with trauma history)

dosing.instructions: Start 1 mg PO qHS; titrate by 1-2 mg q1wk; max 15 mg qHS; monitor for first-dose hypotension (give first dose at bedtime)

Pharmacologic Management of Psychiatric.monitoring: Orthostatic BP (especially first dose); dizziness; syncope; nightmare frequency

Pharmacologic Management of Psychiatric.indication: Acute anxiety; situational anxiety in PNES patients; avoids benzodiazepine use

dosing.instructions: 25-50 mg PO q6-8h PRN anxiety; max 100 mg/dose; non-addictive alternative to benzodiazepines

Pharmacologic Management of Psychiatric.indication: Comorbid generalized anxiety disorder; non-addictive anxiolytic; avoids benzodiazepine dependence

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg PO TID; titrate by 5 mg/day q2-3d; max 60 mg/day; takes 2-4 weeks for full effect (NOT a PRN medication)

Pharmacologic Management of Psychiatric.monitoring: Serotonin syndrome if combined with SSRIs/SNRIs; dizziness; headache

Pharmacologic Management of Psychiatric.indication: Comorbid chronic pain (headache, fibromyalgia); insomnia; migraine prophylaxis in PNES patients

dosing.instructions: Start 10 mg PO qHS; titrate by 10 mg q1-2wk; max 75 mg qHS for pain/insomnia; lower doses effective for pain than depression

Pharmacologic Management of Psychiatric.contraindications: Cardiac conduction abnormality; recent MI; urinary retention; narrow-angle glaucoma; elderly (anticholinergic burden)
Pharmacologic Management of Psychiatric.monitoring: ECG if dose >50 mg; anticholinergic effects (dry mouth, constipation, urinary retention); sedation; orthostatic hypotension; weight gain

Pharmacologic Management of Psychiatric.indication: Insomnia (common PNES comorbidity); adjunct for depression; avoids benzodiazepine hypnotics

dosing.instructions: 25-100 mg PO qHS for insomnia; max 150 mg qHS

Pharmacologic Management of Psychiatric.monitoring: Orthostatic hypotension; priapism (rare -- counsel male patients); sedation; QTc

dosing.instructions: 3-10 mg PO qHS; take 30-60 min before bedtime; max 10 mg

Anti-Seizure Medication Taper.indication: Confirmed PNES on levetiracetam without comorbid epilepsy; taper AFTER definitive vEEG diagnosis

doseOptions.orderSentence: Gradual ASM taper -- levetiracetam 250-500 mg reduction PO

dosing.instructions: Taper by 250-500 mg every 2 weeks; typical taper from 1000 mg BID over 8-12 weeks; monitor for anxiety/mood changes (levetiracetam withdrawal can worsen mood)
dosing.orderSentence: Gradual ASM taper -- levetiracetam 250-500 mg reduction PO

Anti-Seizure Medication Taper.contraindications: Comorbid epilepsy confirmed or suspected (~10% dual diagnosis); do NOT taper without epileptologist input in dual-diagnosis patients
Anti-Seizure Medication Taper.monitoring: Event frequency diary; mood (levetiracetam withdrawal may improve mood or cause rebound anxiety); verify no epileptiform events during taper

Anti-Seizure Medication Taper.indication: Confirmed PNES on lamotrigine without comorbid epilepsy

doseOptions.orderSentence: Gradual ASM taper -- lamotrigine 25-50 mg reduction PO

dosing.instructions: Taper by 25-50 mg every 2 weeks; slower taper than other ASMs (lamotrigine has mood-stabilizing properties -- monitor for mood destabilization)
dosing.orderSentence: Gradual ASM taper -- lamotrigine 25-50 mg reduction PO

Anti-Seizure Medication Taper.contraindications: Comorbid epilepsy; bipolar disorder (lamotrigine may be serving as mood stabilizer)
Anti-Seizure Medication Taper.monitoring: Event frequency; mood stability (PHQ-9, mood diary); rash (rare during taper but document)

Anti-Seizure Medication Taper.indication: Confirmed PNES on valproic acid without comorbid epilepsy

doseOptions.orderSentence: Gradual ASM taper -- valproic acid 250 mg reduction PO

dosing.instructions: Taper by 250 mg every 2 weeks; monitor for mood changes (valproate has mood-stabilizing properties); check levels during taper if comorbid epilepsy cannot be fully excluded
dosing.orderSentence: Gradual ASM taper -- valproic acid 250 mg reduction PO

Anti-Seizure Medication Taper.contraindications: Comorbid epilepsy; bipolar disorder (valproate may be serving as mood stabilizer)
Anti-Seizure Medication Taper.monitoring: Event frequency; mood; weight (may lose weight with taper); LFTs; tremor (may improve with taper)

Anti-Seizure Medication Taper.indication: Confirmed PNES on carbamazepine or oxcarbazepine without comorbid epilepsy

doseOptions.orderSentence: Gradual ASM taper -- carbamazepine/oxcarbazepine 100-200 mg reduction PO

dosing.instructions: Taper by 100-200 mg every 2 weeks; carbamazepine induces its own metabolism (levels may shift during taper); complete taper over 8-12 weeks
dosing.orderSentence: Gradual ASM taper -- carbamazepine/oxcarbazepine 100-200 mg reduction PO

Anti-Seizure Medication Taper.contraindications: Comorbid epilepsy; trigeminal neuralgia (carbamazepine may be treating pain)
Anti-Seizure Medication Taper.monitoring: Event frequency; mood; sodium level (hyponatremia more common with oxcarbazepine -- may resolve with taper); CBC

Anti-Seizure Medication Taper.indication: Confirmed PNES on topiramate without comorbid epilepsy

doseOptions.orderSentence: Gradual ASM taper -- topiramate 25-50 mg reduction PO

dosing.instructions: Taper by 25-50 mg every 1-2 weeks; cognitive side effects may improve with taper; monitor for weight changes
dosing.orderSentence: Gradual ASM taper -- topiramate 25-50 mg reduction PO

Anti-Seizure Medication Taper.contraindications: Comorbid epilepsy; migraine prophylaxis (topiramate may be treating migraines -- assess before taper)
Anti-Seizure Medication Taper.monitoring: Event frequency; cognitive function (may improve); weight; migraine frequency if history of headache

Anti-Seizure Medication Taper.indication: Confirmed PNES on phenobarbital without comorbid epilepsy; REQUIRES SLOW TAPER (barbiturate withdrawal risk)

doseOptions.orderSentence: Gradual ASM taper -- phenobarbital 15-30 mg reduction PO

dosing.instructions: Taper by 15-30 mg every 2-4 weeks; VERY SLOW taper over 3-6 months; barbiturate withdrawal can cause TRUE seizures even in non-epileptic patients; inpatient monitoring may be needed for high doses
dosing.orderSentence: Gradual ASM taper -- phenobarbital 15-30 mg reduction PO

Anti-Seizure Medication Taper.contraindications: Comorbid epilepsy; barbiturate dependence (consider inpatient taper for high doses >120 mg/day)
Anti-Seizure Medication Taper.monitoring: Event frequency; withdrawal symptoms (anxiety, insomnia, tremor, TRUE seizures); vital signs during taper; may need phenobarbital levels

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology (epileptologist preferred) for vEEG confirmation of diagnosis and differentiation from epileptic seizures
Epilepsy monitoring unit (EMU) admission for prolonged video-EEG to capture habitual events and establish definitive diagnosis
Psychiatry with PNES/FND experience for comorbidity assessment (depression, PTSD, anxiety, personality disorder) and medication management
Clinical psychology (CBT-PNES trained) for evidence-based psychotherapy as primary treatment modality
Neuropsychiatry for complex cases with overlapping functional and organic symptoms or diagnostic uncertainty
Social work for disability navigation, vocational rehabilitation, family education, and community resource coordination
Physical therapy for deconditioning and functional motor symptoms that may coexist with PNES
Occupational therapy for return-to-work planning and ADL adaptation during treatment
Primary care follow-up for chronic disease management, medication reconciliation, and psychiatric medication monitoring

Patient Instructions.item: Your events are REAL -- they are caused by your brain sending the wrong signals, like a software problem rather than structural brain damage, and they are NOT fabricated or imagined
The good news is that functional seizures are TREATABLE -- many patients improve significantly or become event-free with the right therapy
Visit www.neurosymptoms.org for reliable, expert-written information about functional seizures (recommended by leading neurologists worldwide)
Anti-seizure medications do NOT work for functional seizures -- your neurologist will work with you to safely taper these medications if you are taking them
Do NOT take extra doses of anti-seizure medication during or after an event -- this will NOT help and may cause side effects
During an event, use grounding techniques: focus on your surroundings, name objects you see, feel textures in your hands, listen to sounds around you -- these techniques can help shorten events

Family members and caregivers: during an event, stay calm, speak reassuringly, do NOT restrain or force anything into the mouth, time the event, and do NOT call 911 unless there is injury or the event is clearly different from usual
Keep a seizure diary recording event frequency, duration, possible triggers (stress, sleep deprivation, conflict), and context to help identify patterns
Attend ALL recommended therapy appointments (psychology and physiotherapy are the primary treatments -- more important than any medication)
Return to the ED only for events that are clearly DIFFERENT from your usual events, for injury during an event, or for new symptoms such as sudden severe headache, fever, or one-sided weakness

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Regular aerobic exercise (30 minutes, 5 days per week) to reduce stress, improve mood, and support overall brain health
Sleep hygiene: consistent bed and wake times, 7-9 hours nightly, avoid screens 1 hour before bed, limit caffeine after noon (sleep deprivation is a common PNES trigger)
Stress management: identify and address major stressors; use breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, or mindfulness daily
Avoid alcohol and recreational drugs (lower event threshold, worsen mood and anxiety, interfere with therapy)
Avoid benzodiazepines for anxiety (not helpful for PNES, can worsen dissociation, and carry addiction risk) -- discuss non-benzodiazepine alternatives with your provider
Pacing: balance activity and rest throughout the day to avoid the "boom-bust" cycle (overexertion on good days leads to increased events on subsequent days)
Maintain social connections and meaningful activities to prevent isolation, which worsens PNES outcomes
Driving restrictions: follow state-specific regulations for seizure-like events; most states require a seizure-free interval (varies by state) -- discuss with your neurologist

differential.features: Stereotyped semiology; eyes OPEN (~95%); postictal confusion (>5 min); tonic-clonic evolution; tongue lateral bite; incontinence; duration typically <3 min
differential.tests: Video-EEG with event capture (gold standard); prolactin level (elevated >2x post-GTC); MRI brain

differential.features: Bizarre motor automatisms; brief (<30 sec); stereotyped; nocturnal predominance; may not show surface EEG changes
differential.tests: Video-EEG (may need intracranial monitoring); MRI brain with epilepsy protocol; seizure semiology analysis

differential.features: Triggered by prolonged standing, pain, or emotional stress; prodrome (lightheadedness, diaphoresis, tunnel vision); brief loss of consciousness; rapid recovery; no postictal confusion
differential.tests: Tilt table test; ECG; history and trigger identification

differential.features: Sudden onset without prodrome; associated with palpitations; may occur during exertion; family history of sudden death
differential.tests: ECG; Holter/event monitor; echocardiogram; cardiac electrophysiology study

differential.features: Sudden onset fear; palpitations; chest pain; dyspnea; paresthesias; derealization; duration 10-30 min; preserved consciousness
differential.tests: Clinical history; GAD-7/PHQ-9; panic typically does not involve rhythmic movements or unresponsiveness

differential.features: Sudden focal neurological deficit; duration <24 hours; vascular risk factors; arterial territory distribution
differential.tests: MRI brain (DWI); CT angiography; vascular risk factor assessment

differential.features: Brief, stereotyped movement episodes; may be triggered by sudden movement (kinesigenic); genetic basis; responsive to carbamazepine (kinesigenic type)
differential.tests: Genetic testing (PRRT2 for PKD); clinical semiology; family history; treatment trial

differential.features: Visual or sensory aura with gradual spread; followed by headache; duration 5-60 min for aura; episodic
differential.tests: Clinical history; headache diary; MRI brain to rule out structural lesion

differential.features: Diaphoresis; tremor; confusion; pallor; triggered by fasting or insulin administration; rapid resolution with glucose
differential.tests: Blood glucose during event; continuous glucose monitoring; HbA1c

differential.features: Excessive daytime sleepiness; cataplexy triggered by emotion (laughter, surprise); sleep paralysis; hypnagogic hallucinations
differential.tests: Polysomnography; MSLT (mean sleep latency test); CSF hypocretin level

differential.features: Intentional symptom production; external motivation in malingering, sick role in factitious; VERY RARE -- do NOT assume
differential.tests: No reliable test; clinical judgment; inconsistency with incentives; PNES is NOT malingering or factitious

evidence.recommendation: Video-EEG with event capture is the gold standard for PNES diagnosis
CBT is effective for reducing PNES event frequency (CODES trial -- largest RCT)
Diagnosis delivery communication is the single most important therapeutic intervention
Comorbid epilepsy in ~10% of PNES patients (dual diagnosis prevalence)
ILAE diagnostic certainty levels for PNES (Possible/Probable/Established/Documented)
Prolactin level utility: elevated post-GTC but not post-PNES (~60% sensitivity)
Semiology features distinguishing PNES from epileptic seizures (eyes closed, duration, etc.)
PNES epidemiology: 2-33 per 100,000; 20-30% of epilepsy monitoring unit referrals
Benzodiazepines are ineffective and harmful for PNES events; cause iatrogenic respiratory depression
Specialized physiotherapy effective for functional neurological disorder (including PNES with motor symptoms)
evidence.source: [Nielsen G et al. J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry 2015;86:1113-1119](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/25433033/)

evidence.recommendation: Anti-seizure medication taper in confirmed PNES: safe and recommended
PTSD comorbidity in 30-50% of PNES patients; trauma history as risk factor
evidence.source: [Fiszman A et al. J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry 2004;75:1009-1012](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/15645062/)

evidence.recommendation: Psychiatric comorbidity (depression, anxiety) in >80% of PNES patients
Patient preference for term "functional seizures" over "psychogenic"
neurosymptoms.org: validated patient education resource for FND/PNES
DSM-5 diagnostic criteria for conversion disorder with seizures (F44.5)
NES Treatment Guidelines: comprehensive management recommendations

monitoring.action: Reassess treatment plan; intensify psychotherapy; address perpetuating factors; review triggers
If character changes (new features), reassess for comorbid epilepsy or new diagnosis
Adjust antidepressant; intensify psychological treatment; psychiatric referral for refractory depression
Adjust anxiolytic; psychological treatment; consider SNRI or buspirone if not responding

monitoring.frequency: Baseline and q8-12 weeks if PTSD comorbidity
monitoring.action: Adjust trauma therapy; consider EMDR; prazosin for nightmares; psychiatric referral
Explore barriers (transportation, financial, stigma); motivational interviewing; modify modality if needed
If new event types appear during taper, obtain EEG; consider dual diagnosis; slow or pause taper
Vocational rehabilitation; occupational therapy; graded return plan; address disability perpetuation
Dose adjustment; medication switch; reassess risk-benefit
Reassess treatment components; multidisciplinary team review

disposition.criteria: Event resolved; patient hemodynamically stable; no injury requiring treatment; diagnosis communicated (or follow-up arranged for formal diagnosis delivery); outpatient neurology follow-up arranged within 2-4 weeks; patient educated that these events are not life-threatening; family educated on event management (do not call 911 for typical events unless injury or clearly different from usual)

Video-EEG monitoring needed for diagnostic confirmation; diagnostic uncertainty requiring observation; recurrent ED presentations for events requiring care coordination and definitive diagnosis; concurrent ASM taper requiring monitoring (phenobarbital, high-dose benzodiazepines)

Generally NOT indicated for PNES; consider ONLY if: iatrogenic complication from inappropriate treatment (respiratory depression from benzodiazepines); diagnostic uncertainty with ongoing concern for status epilepticus requiring continuous EEG
Active suicidality; severe psychiatric decompensation; psychosis; inability to maintain safety in outpatient setting
Video-EEG monitoring not available at current facility; epilepsy monitoring unit referral; PNES-specialized treatment program not available locally

ALL patients: neurology follow-up within 2-4 weeks for diagnosis delivery and treatment planning; psychology referral within 1-2 weeks; psychiatry for comorbidity management within 1 month; PCP within 1-2 weeks for medication reconciliation
